awd_titl_txt: Analyzing and Exploiting Hybrid Dynamical Systems Containing Piecewise Linear Nonlinearities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance national interests by supporting research that will improve the design process of a variety of engineered systems where rubbing and intermittent contact between components significantly affects performance. These systems include damping devices for aircraft engines and turbomachinery, and energy harvesters such as water buoys that provide green energy. Current techniques are not able to predict the response of these complex systems and hence obstruct the development of new technologies. This research will provide new techniques to advance the design process of next-generation damping devices and energy harvesters. The optimal damper design will address serious fatigue problems and reduce required maintenance costs for flight vehicles and turbomachinery. This research will also create a new class of energy harvesting methods that will provide better power generation efficiency. The research will be integrated with an educational component disseminating the work to undergraduates and kindergarten through eighth grade underrepresented groups to help broaden participation in research and positively impact engineering education.

Prediction and exploitation of the dynamics of complex systems with dry friction and/or intermittent contact is challenging due to the lack of computational efficiency and limited capability of current methods to analyze the induced piecewise-linear nonlinearities. This research will create a new class of effective techniques to enable the computation of the responses, both transient and steady-state, of large piecewise-linear nonlinear systems in order to analyze, monitor and control their dynamics. This research has three main goals. First, create a method to compute the time-domain response of complex systems with piecewise-linear nonlinearities. The project's approach enables the analysis of any type of response (e.g., periodic, quasi-periodic, and chaotic responses) of these systems. Second, create a method to rapidly approximate the steady-state vibration amplitudes and frequencies of large piecewise-linear nonlinear systems when they respond periodically. Parametric and statistical studies and new vibration control strategies of these systems will be enabled with this method. Third, apply the general methods to two real-world applications: the analysis of turbomachinery containing nonlinear damping and the active gap control for improved vibration performance of energy harvesters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on creating more effective modeling tools for complex systems that have piecewise linear (PWL) nonlinearity. These PWL systems are common in engineered structures and nature–they exist in many contexts including whenever there are joints, a gap between parts that leads to intermittent contact, or surfaces where objects rub against each other. During the project, multiple tools were developed and experimentally validated. Because these PWL systems are ubiquitous, these tools can be used in many applications. This work focused on using these new tools for two specific applications to demonstrate their effectiveness and broad applicability.

The first application was energy harvesting. For this application, a new type of PWL energy harvester was created—one that operates effectively over a large range of excitations by changing the system properties to match the excitation source. This new harvester is better than traditional linear harvesters, which only work for a specific excitation frequency. Also, when there is a dominant excitation source for the harvester to lock onto, the new tool is more effective than typical broad band harvesters. More effective energy harvesters have wide applicability and can lead to self-powered sensors to monitor the health of civil (i.e., bridges and buildings) and industrial (i.e., manufacturing and heavy machinery) infrastructure. Beyond that, large-scale energy harvesters can power the electric grid through a renewable energy source like wave energy.

The second application these new tools were applied to was turbomachinery (e.g., found in aircraft engines or power plants).  In this work, new methods were created to reduce the complex and nonlinear turbomachinery models into much smaller models that can be analyzed statistically to better design these systems. These smaller models were integrated with new, fundamental PWL analysis tools also developed in this work. In particular, models for turbines with cracks that lead to intermittent contact and dampers (i.e., friction parts placed at specific locations on the disk that dissipate vibration energy by rubbing in the disk) were created, validated, and analyzed. These new integrated tools can improve the design and analysis process to build more effective, reliable, and safer gas turbines.

During this project, several undergraduate, MS and PhD students were trained in highly specialized skills. Moreover, three of the undergraduate students developed engineering design challenges that they presented to middle school classrooms to increase interest in STEM careers. Also, one of the PhD students participated in the INTERN program, where they interned at a small business and gained critical industrial experience.


Last Modified: 06/03/2024
Modified by: Kiran X D'souza
